data.title: The Best Black Documentaries
data.meta_description: The Best Black Documentaries, as voted on by fans. Current Top 3: Tina, MLK/FBI, Summer of Soul
data.text:
Ranked By

752 votes

32 voters

Voting Rules

Vote up your favorite documentaries.

What are the best black documentary films or series? The best black documentary movies and docuseries offer strong calls to action, memorable stories of triumph, and emotional payoffs that stick with you long after they're over. Black documentaries focus on a variety of subjects around in both subtle and more overt manners from black history documentaries to the black lives matter movement to stories of black excellence. They also come from big studios and independent distributors. So, what is the best black documentary? What documentaries about the black experience should you watch first?

The best black documentary movies, like I Am Not Your Negro, have even found themselves nominated for and winning awards. In every way, these are some of the most important documentaries of our time. On this list, you'll find the black panther documentary The Black Panthers Vanguard of the Revolution, the black wall street documentary Tulsa Burning: The 1921 Race Massacre, and many more great black documentaries, such as The Black Power Mixtape 1967-1975, John Lewis: Good Trouble, Summer of Soul, and Black Art: In the Absence of Light.

You can find some these black documentaries on Netflix, while others are available on streaming services like HBO Max, Hulu, Paramount+, and Amazon Prime.

Vote up the best black documentaries to make sure they make it to the top of the list. Be sure to check back for new black docs as they are added to the list upon release.

Latest additions: Black Barbie: A Documentary, Madu, Sacred Soil: The Piney Woods School Story

Help shape these rankings by voting on this list of The Best Black Documentaries

Actors : Angela Bassett, Tina Turner, Oprah Winfrey

Released : 2021

Directed by : Dan Lindsay, T.J. Martin

Never-before-seen footage, audio tapes, personal photos and intimate interviews provide insight into the remarkable life and career of legendary singer Tina Turner.

Actors : James Comey, Beverly Gage, Martin Luther King Jr.

Released : 2020

Directed by : Sam Pollard

Filmmaker Sam Pollard examines the U.S. government surveillance of Martin Luther King Jr., based on recently declassified files.

Actors : Stevie Wonder, Chris Rock, Nina Simone, Lin Manuel Miranda, Jesse Jackson

Released : 2021

Directed by : Questlove

Over the course of six weeks during the summer of 1969, thousands of people attend the Harlem Cultural Festival to celebrate Black history, culture, music and fashion.

Actors : William Gates, Arthur Agee, Sheila Agee, Isiah Thomas, Bill Gleason

Released : 1994

Directed by : Steve James

Hoop Dreams is a compelling documentary that chronicles the lives of two Chicago high school students, William Gates and Arthur Agee (themselves), who dream of becoming professional basketball players. The film, directed by Steve James, delves into the harsh realities of their journey, from academic pressures to family struggles. It's not just about sports; it's an exploration of American life, aspirations, and societal structures. Garnering critical acclaim, Hoop Dreams won the Audience Award for Best Documentary at Sundance in 1994. This is a narrative of perseverance and ambition against all odds.

5

Freedom Riders

Film

Actors : Raymond Arsenault, Genevieve Houghton, Gordon Carey

Released : 2010

Directed by : Stanley Nelson Jr.

Freedom Riders is a 2010 American historical documentary film, produced by Firelight Media for PBS American Experience based in part on the book Freedom Riders: 1961 and the Struggle for Racial Justice by historian Raymond Arsenault. Directed by Stanley Nelson, it marked the 50th anniversary of the first Freedom Ride in May 1961 and was first aired on May 16, 2011. The film chronicles the story behind hundreds of civil rights activists called the Freedom Riders who challenged the racial segregation of the American interstate transport and by traveling together in small interracial groups and sitting where they chose on the buses and trains to demand equal access to terminal restaurants and waiting rooms, and to bring racial segregation national attention. The film is currently used within Firelight Media’s national outreach campaign, to serve as an educational and advocacy tool by NGOs and non-profit partners in order to support young people who are mobilizing around contemporary social issues such as, immigrant rights, youth violence, and environmental issues. The film was also featured on The Oprah Winfrey Show program titled, Freedom Riders: 50th Anniversary.

Actors : Angela Davis, Stokely Carmichael, Bobby Seale

Released : 2011

Directed by : Göran Olsson

The Black Power Mixtape examines the evolution of the Black Power Movement in the black community and Diaspora from 1967 to 1975. The film combines music, startling 16mm footage (lying undiscovered in the cellar of Swedish Television for 30 years), and contemporary audio interviews from leading African-American artists, activists, musicians and scholars.
